bounty.title: Improve login time
bounty.html:
The time it takes a user to login to GNOME has not changed very much in the last five years, despite massive improvements in hardware performance. Some analysis has shown that login time is bounded by a heavy I/O load. Havoc Pennington has pointed out a 3-4 second delay caused by GConf initialization.

This bounty will go to the person (or team) who submits a maintainer-accepted patch which results in the single largest reduction in login time.

bounty.title: Reduce Evolution memory usage
bounty.html: This bounty will go to the person who submits the best accepted patch to Evolution which results in the greatest reduction of run-time memory usage under ordinary usage. Memory reductions to the mailer, addressbook and calendar will all be considered.

bounty.title: Live documentation editing
bounty.html: Implement a live web-based wiki-like editor that allows generation of content that can be rolled back into our documentation. Allows users to contribute annotations and additions to documentation (e.g. can add documentation to an undocumented function), save it. Other people visiting the page will see your additions to the documentation, and the maintainer of the module can extract the addition and trivially roll it into the official documentation source.

bounty.title: Gnome architecture overview
bounty.html: Write a document giving an overview of the GNOME development platform's architecture. The target audience for this document includes developers who want to begin developing software on GNOME, people who want to begin contributing to GNOME, or system administrators who want a better understanding of how the pieces fit together. This bounty will go to the authors of the best paper.

bounty.title: library.gnome.org
Most unprecedented application
bounty.html:
Have an idea you think no one's ever had before? An innovative application that doesn't exist but that everyone needs? Something so cool it just has to be done?

This bounty will be awarded to the authors of the most unprecedented application. Submissions will be judged by a panel appointed by the GNOME board of directors.

bounty.title: Panel applet bundle system
bounty.html: A framework that lets developers implement panel extensions as simple to write single file bundles. Bundles will require no native code, probably written in Python (so they work between library versions etc), and will be user installable from web pages. Must include a tool for building the bundles.

bounty.title: Group mails by conversations in Evolution
bounty.html: Gmail provides an innovative new way of reading your emails: as conversations wherein the mails you send and the mails you receive in a given thread are all visible once, in chronological order. Implement this in Evolution.

bounty.title: Paste by example
bounty.html: Paste by example is a feature that allows users to learn "by example" the features of an office suite. It will let people learn to create any formatting or object seen in a document sent to them (or one they created 3 years ago). Office objects in the clipboard buffer (e.g. a graph or a formatted sentence) can be pasted into the current document, but step by step as a dynamically generated tutorial (showing the dialogues and commands users could have used to recreate the object in question). Feature can be implemented in OpenOffice.org or AbiWord.

bounty.title: Search party
bounty.html: Search party is a feature that allows adhoc chat rooms to form based on what people are searching for on the web (using e.g. Google). Implement the search party web browser extension for Firefox or Epiphany. Define the search party client/server "protocol" and implement a server. Mockups and More Details

bounty.title: Shared music spaces
bounty.html: Shared music spaces allow people in a shared chat room (e.g. an IM chat room) to listen to a music stream playing on any of their computers. Feature will be added using Rhythmbox and Gaim.

bounty.title: Conference content
bounty.html: Develop a complete set of content for shows. This includes posters, imagery, and brochures targeted toward different purposes (prospective developers, trade shows, corporate sponsors, etc)

bounty.title: The GIMP resource distribution system
bounty.html: Develop a distribution system for brushes, palettes, patterns, gradients, plug-ins, scripts and any other resources of The GIMP that are available. It should be usable from within GIMP and be available on any platform GIMP can be run on.

bounty.title: The GIMP vector based shapes tool
bounty.html: The GIMP urgently needs a tool to draw shapes (rectangles, ellipses, polygons, stars, clouds, speech bubbles ... based on vectors.

bounty.title: National, religious, event calendars
bounty.html:
In Evolution 2.0, users can aggregate multiple simultaneous calendar sources into a single view. This means that you can overlay group calendars and other people's calendars into your own calendar view, which helps you keep others in mind while you schedule your life. The various backend calendars can even be color-coded in the calendar view.

We would like Evolution to ship with a large number of calendars containing the schedules for national holidays, religious holidays, and other events of general interest. For example, calendars of sporting events or a Linux conference schedule would be neat.

Because Evolution 2.0 allows you to specify a URL to a calendar, it is even possible for these to be hosted online and cached locally. This might be useful for things like the GNOME release schedule.

This task probably won't involve patching any existing modules, though we will include any accepted calendars in the module.

Find and check the schedules for various types of events, and create a calendar in the standard iCal format. Submit the calendar file or files, along with a short description, to evolution-patches@ximian.com.

Until Evolution provides an 'Export' mechanism, the files should be copied (if created in Evolution) from the Evolution2.0 tree, that is ~/.evolution/calendar/local/OnThisComputer/"name", where "name" is the name of the calendar you created. If created in Evolution 1.4, the file to copy is ~/evolution/local/Calendar/subfolders/"name".

The following links might be helpful:
  • Evolution users list
  • Apple's iCalShare site
  • , the iCalendar specification
  • The calendar publication task is obviously somewhat related.
Please note that downloading proprietary .ical files and submitting them is not acceptable. To collect this bounty, you must provide an unencumbered, freely-licensed (X11) iCalendar file. The bounty for this task is per-calendar. We will pay bounties for up to 30 calendars.

bounty.title: "Me"
bounty.html:
The Evolution 2.0 addressbook will have a "me" concept that will allow programs to get the contact entry that corresponds to the user. This should be integrated across the desktop, wherever extensive user information (name, email address, etc) is needed or entered.

A couple of places where other applications could use this data:

  • Web forms, via Firefox's form autofill feature.
  • Document author fields in OpenOffice.

contains the function e_book_get_self, which can be used to retrieve the contact associated with the user. From there you can use the methods on EContact to retrieve the bits of information you need.

bounty.title: Drag-n-drop task creation
bounty.html: It would be handy to be able to create tasks in Evolution by dragging a mail, file or link into the tasks folder. See <?php bug(4006); ?>.

bounty.title: OO.o slides side-pane
bounty.html:
When editing a slide in the drawing view, it is often helpful to have some context. We need to add a side-pane that provides a scrollable vertical 'slide view' of the presentation.

It is assumed that the existing 'slide view' widget can be re-used here, in a scroll pane.

As the user edits a slide, its appearance in the side view should change at a reasonable rate. The side view should be sensibly sized & aesthetically pleasing. The user should be able to navigate among slides by selecting them in the side view.

bounty.title: Calendar attachments
bounty.html:
Add support in evolution for attaching files to events.

The iCalendar specification, , describes a property ATTACH (4.8.1.1) for attaching data to an iCalendar object (event or task). The event and task editor should allow the user to add and remove documents and files. It should also allow the user to open the attached using an appropriate mime handler (similar to Nautilus or the mail portion of evolution)

The following picture illustrates the point:

To attach file, drag it on the event. The event should draw a two pixel black outline to give visual feedback to "drag accept". You should also be able to attach documents with a right-click menu. There should be a contextual menu item to open the editor and get the list of files and documents


The first step is to confirm that supports the ATTACH property properly. You will want to check that icalrecur.h and icalrecur.c are adequate and that icalparser.c correctly reads in the ATTACH property. If it does not, you will need to correct that.

The second step is to to allow drag and drop of files on the day view, week view and list view calendar items and the task list item (see e-day-view.c, e-week-view.c and e-cal-list-view. in ). It can accept the file uri drop, look up the event and then attach the item.

The third step is to create a page containing the attachment information for the editor, and add it to the event editor and task editors, and example of this is recurrence-page.c in . There should also be an "Attach" button that pops up a file dialog. The page should not be visible unless there are attachments or the user clicks the "Attach" button. Double clicking and attachment should allow the user to open the item with an appropriate handler. You might design this page similar to the mail composer's attachment area.

The fourth step is to add contextual menu item, "Edit Attachments..." that should open the editor and display the attachments page. a similar thing is done by the "Schedule Meeting..." context item.

You should subscribe to the evolution-hackers mailing list, and discuss any technical issues there. Rodrigo Moya <rodrigo@ximian.com> and Hans Petter Jansson <hpj@ximian.com> will be the primary contacts on the list for the Calendar.

bounty.title: Choice of database for contacts back-end
bounty.html:
Some people or system administrators want to use a local address back-end that is not the default (db3). The most popular request is SQLite, but a generalized SQL interface would be best.

You will need to choose or design a database schema to match the Evolution addressbook, and then write wrappers to translate the Evolution addressbook manipulation functions to your choice of database. It is acceptable to leave database selection as an option 'hidden' in gconf-editor. For the implementation, libgda seems the best choice for the database access part, since it allows access to many different database backends (PostgreSQL, MySQL, SQLite, SQL Server, Oracle, etc) and offers a rich data management API.

You'll be working on , writing a new addressbook backend.
  • libgda API reference

bounty.title: OO.o slide view performance
bounty.html:
The slides view in impress suffers some from seriously slow, un-cached slide thumbnailing, this makes scrolling the slide list unacceptably slow.

Either profile and accelerate the thumbnail rendering to an acceptable level, or render slides to a bitmap that can be rendered more quickly subsequently.

The solution providing the greatest speedup, and ergonomic improvement in this area wins
